title: WillyAp
author: WillyAp
content: Reading about China, Korrea and the US on X first. Anniversay is it almost. A comment of a chinese based tweet made it clear that the conflict is kinda probable. It lead to further searches about the the silent treatment China has nowadays for the US Military. https://archive.is/20230725185024/https://www.foreignaffairs.com/united-states/why-china-wont-talk-americas-militaryWhich led to the Korrean-USA-China triangle. The Battle of Chosin:https://www.britannica.com/event/Battle-of-the-Chosin-ReservoirWhat do you think? Am I the only one believeing that conflict is kinda inevitable? Hawks are on both sides.

comments.author: paxmao
comments.body: I would not say innevitable but is one of the options for the proxy war that one day may arise from the US and China pissing context in Asia. A very bad conflict if it goes ahead, since both Koreas are armed to a ridiculous grade, NK has nukes, even a nuclear sub and SK has probably the best and most concentrated artillery in the world.

The inevitable war is China-Taiwan-USA + the rest. Predicted in 2 years time. Highly likely if the government of China stay the same. I think the Korean conflict in 1950 is mentioned in the Britannia Article and one note was there which made it clear: QuoteNevertheless, the campaign ruined the CPVF Ninth Army Group, which did not return to the front until March 1951, and it convinced the UNC that allied ground troops could defeat Chinese armies, however numerous.

comments.author: Hispo
comments.body: I have not seen much of an indication of escalation between North Korea and the West lately, just some inauguration of a nuclear submarine and the typical nuclear tests which NK carries out.Perhaps, we could speculate that since North Korea could be aiding the Klemlin with the war effort against the people of Ukraine, then it has become a priority to try to pressure both China and North Korea from helping Putin.It is easier to pressure China than it is to pressure Nk, I think, since Pekin has very important volume of commerce with the United States and the European Union, while NK has little to nothing to lose in the case of more sanctions.
